[30;1m133 | [0m[35m- Added optional `height` parameter to Label constructor.[0m

[30;1m135 | [0m[35m  in a Frame explicitly rather than relying on reset to blank out uninitialized fields.[0m

[30;1m726 | [0m[35m                self._path.reset()[0m

[30;1m14 | [0m[35mclass Effect(metaclass=ABCMeta):[0m
[30;1m15 | [0m[35m    """[0m
[30;1m16 | [0m[35m    Abstract class to handle a special effect on the screen.  An Effect can[0m
[30;1m17 | [0m[35m    cover anything from a static image at the start of the Scene through to[0m
[30;1m18 | [0m[35m    dynamic animations that need to be redrawn for every frame.[0m
[30;1m19 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m20 | [0m[35m    The basic interaction with a :py:obj:`.Scene` is as follows:[0m

[30;1m1124 | [0m[35m        """[0m

[30;1m91 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m76 | [0m[35mHow to use it?[0m
[30;1m77 | [0m[35m--------------[0m
[30;1m78 | [0m[35mTo use the low-level API, simply create a Screen and use it to print coloured text at any location,[0m
[30;1m79 | [0m[35mor get mouse/keyboard input.  For example, here is a variant on the classic "hello world":[0m
[30;1m80 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m81 | [0m[35m.. code-block:: python[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m526[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m64 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m65 | [0m[35mTo install asciimatics, simply install with `pip` as follows:[0m
[30;1m66 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m67 | [0m[35m.. code-block:: bash[0m
[30;1m68 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m69 | [0m[35m    $ pip install asciimatics[0m
[30;1m70 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m71 | [0m[35mThis should install all your dependencies for you.  If you don't use pip or it fails to install[0m

[30;1m259 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m260 | [0m[35m    Some languages use double-width glyphs.  When scraping text for such glyphs, you will find that[0m
[30;1m261 | [0m[35m    ``get_from`` returns the character for both of the 2 locations containing the glyph.  For[0m
[30;1m262 | [0m[35m    example, if you printed ``是`` at ``(0, 0)``, you would find that asciimatics returns this value[0m
[30;1m263 | [0m[35m    for both ``(0, 0)`` and ``(0, 1)``.  For more details on which languages (and hence unicode[0m
[30;1m264 | [0m[35m    characters) are affected by this see, `here[0m
[30;1m265 | [0m[35m    <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halfwidth_and_fullwidth_forms>`__ and `here[0m

[30;1m243 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m244 | [0m[35mScraping Text[0m
[30;1m245 | [0m[35m-------------[0m
[30;1m246 | [0m[35mSometimes it is useful to be able to read what is already displayed on the Screen at a given[0m
[30;1m247 | [0m[35mlocation.  This is often referred to as screen scraping.  You can do this using the[0m
[30;1m248 | [0m[35m:py:meth:`~.Screen.get_from` method.  It will return the displayed character and attributes (as a[0m
[30;1m249 | [0m[35m4-tuple) for any single character location on the Screen.[0m

[30;1m236 | [0m[35man exception if this happens while you are playing a Scene by specifying ``stop_on_resize=True``.[0m

[30;1m167 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m168 | [0m[35mApplications are required to re-render everything that needs to be displayed and then call refresh[0m
[30;1m169 | [0m[35mwhen all the new content is ready.  Note that the :py:meth:`.play` and :py:meth:`.draw_next_frame`[0m
[30;1m170 | [0m[35mmethods will do this for you automatically at the end of each frame, so you don't need to call it[0m
[30;1m171 | [0m[35magain inside your animations.[0m
[30;1m172 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m173 | [0m[35mInput[0m

[30;1m155 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m156 | [0m[35mClearing the Screen[0m
[30;1m157 | [0m[35m^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^[0m
[30;1m158 | [0m[35mOnce you have started your application, you will likely want to clear parts, or all, of the Screen[0m
[30;1m159 | [0m[35mat times.  The recommended way to do that is using :py:meth:`~.Screen.clear_buffer`.  This prevents[0m
[30;1m160 | [0m[35mthe flicker that you will see if you tried using the previously mentioned `clear` method instead.[0m
[30;1m161 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m290 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m291 | [0m[35mIn addition, there is the :py:meth:`~.Screen.fill_polygon` method which will draw a filled[0m
[30;1m292 | [0m[35mpolygon in the specified colour using a set of points passed in to define the required shape.  This[0m
[30;1m293 | [0m[35muses the scan-line algorithm, so you can cut holes inside the shape by defining one polygon inside[0m
[30;1m294 | [0m[35manother.  For example:[0m
[30;1m295 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m296 | [0m[35m.. code-block:: python[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m644[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m267 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m268 | [0m[35mDrawing shapes[0m
[30;1m269 | [0m[35m--------------[0m
[30;1m270 | [0m[35mThe Screen object also provides some anti-aliased line drawing facilities, using ASCII characters[0m
[30;1m271 | [0m[35mto represent the line.  The :py:meth:`~.Screen.move` method will move the drawing cursor to the[0m
[30;1m272 | [0m[35mspecified coordinates and then the :py:meth:`~.Screen.draw` method will draw a straight line from[0m
[30;1m273 | [0m[35mthe current cursor location to the specified coordinates.[0m

[30;1m259 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m260 | [0m[35m    Some languages use double-width glyphs.  When scraping text for such glyphs, you will find that[0m
[30;1m261 | [0m[35m    ``get_from`` returns the character for both of the 2 locations containing the glyph.  For[0m
[30;1m262 | [0m[35m    example, if you printed ``是`` at ``(0, 0)``, you would find that asciimatics returns this value[0m
[30;1m263 | [0m[35m    for both ``(0, 0)`` and ``(0, 1)``.  For more details on which languages (and hence unicode[0m
[30;1m264 | [0m[35m    characters) are affected by this see, `here[0m
[30;1m265 | [0m[35m    <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halfwidth_and_fullwidth_forms>`__ and `here[0m

[30;1m163 | [0m[35m---------------------[0m

[30;1m166 | [0m[35mmethod is called.  This is done to reduce flicker on the display device as new content is created.[0m

[30;1m156 | [0m[35mClearing the Screen[0m
[30;1m157 | [0m[35m^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^[0m
[30;1m158 | [0m[35mOnce you have started your application, you will likely want to clear parts, or all, of the Screen[0m
[30;1m159 | [0m[35mat times.  The recommended way to do that is using :py:meth:`~.Screen.clear_buffer`.  This prevents[0m
[30;1m160 | [0m[35mthe flicker that you will see if you tried using the previously mentioned `clear` method instead.[0m
[30;1m161 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m162 | [0m[35mRefreshing the Screen[0m

[30;1m156 | [0m[35mClearing the Screen[0m
[30;1m157 | [0m[35m^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^[0m
[30;1m158 | [0m[35mOnce you have started your application, you will likely want to clear parts, or all, of the Screen[0m
[30;1m159 | [0m[35mat times.  The recommended way to do that is using :py:meth:`~.Screen.clear_buffer`.  This prevents[0m
[30;1m160 | [0m[35mthe flicker that you will see if you tried using the previously mentioned `clear` method instead.[0m

[30;1m72 | [0m[35mThere is a long history to terminals and this is no more obvious than when it comes to colours.[0m
[30;1m73 | [0m[35mOriginal terminals had limited colours, and so used attributes to change the format, using effects[0m
[30;1m74 | [0m[35mlike bold, underline and reverse video.  As time wore on, more colours were added and you can get[0m

[30;1m76 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m77 | [0m[35mFor now, asciimatics limits itself to a maximum of the 256 colour palette.  You can find how many[0m

[30;1m851 | [0m[35mWhen the running `Scene` is resized (and passed back into the Screen as the start scene), the new[0m
[30;1m852 | [0m[35m`Scene` will run through all the `Effects` in the old copy looking for any with a `clone` method.[0m
[30;1m853 | [0m[35mIf it finds one, it will call it with 2 parameters: the new `Screen` and the new `Scene` to own the[0m
[30;1m854 | [0m[35mcloned `Effect`.  This allows you to take full control of how the new `Effect` is recreated.[0m
[30;1m855 | [0m[35mAsciimatics uses this interface in 2 ways by default:[0m
[30;1m856 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m857 | [0m[35m1.  To ensure that any :py:obj:`~.Frame.data` is restored in the new `Scene`.[0m

[30;1m753 | [0m[35mThat done, there are just a few more final touches to consider.  These all touch on dynamically chan[0m
[30;1m754 | [0m[35mreconstructing your Scene.[0m
[30;1m755 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m756 | [0m[35mAt a high level, you need to decide what you want to achieve.  The basic options are as follows.[0m
[30;1m757 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m758 | [0m[35m1. If you just want to have some extra Frames on the same Screen - e.g. pop-up windows - that's[0m
[30;1m759 | [0m[35m   fine.  Just use the existing classes (see below)![0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m696[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m744 | [0m[35m   model (typically as a parameter on construction).[0m
[30;1m745 | [0m[35m3. Use that saved reference to the model to handle updates as needed inside your view's callbacks or[0m
[30;1m746 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m748 | [0m[35mthe ``ContactModel``.  Alternatively, the quick_model sample shows how the same forms would work wit[0m
[30;1m749 | [0m[35mlist of dictionaries instead.[0m
[30;1m750 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m700[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m673 | [0m[35m~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~[0m
[30;1m674 | [0m[35mBack in the days when terminals really were separate machines connected over wires to a computer,[0m
[30;1m675 | [0m[35mit was necessary to be able to signal that the terminal needed time to catch up.  This was done[0m
[30;1m676 | [0m[35musing software flow control, using the Ctrl+S/Ctrl+Q control codes to tell the computer to[0m
[30;1m677 | [0m[35mstop/restart sending text.[0m
[30;1m678 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m679 | [0m[35mThese days, it's not really necessary, but is still a supported feature on most terminals.  On[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m701[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m650 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m651 | [0m[35m    Note that the global handler is only called if the focus does not process the event.  Some[0m
[30;1m652 | [0m[35m    widgets - e.g. TextBox - take any printable text and so the only keys that always get to this[0m
[30;1m653 | [0m[35m    handler are the control codes.  Others will sometimes get here depending on the type of Widget[0m
[30;1m654 | [0m[35m    in focus and whether the Frame is modal or not..[0m
[30;1m655 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m656 | [0m[35mBy default, the global handler will do nothing if you are playing any Scenes containing a Frame.[0m

[30;1m564 | [0m[35mfind out what they entered?  There are 2 basic ways to do this:[0m
[30;1m565 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m566 | [0m[35m1. You can query each Widget directly, using the `value` property.  This returns the current value[0m
[30;1m567 | [0m[35m   the user has entered at any time (even when the Frame is not active).  Note that it may be[0m

[30;1m552 | [0m[35min each of the Widgets - e.g. to pre-populate known values in a form?  There are 2 ways to handle th[0m
[30;1m553 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m554 | [0m[35m1. You can set the value directly on each `Widget` using the :py:obj:`~.Widget.value` property.[0m
[30;1m555 | [0m[35m2. You can set the value for all Widgets in a `Frame` by setting at the :py:obj:`~.Frame.data` prope[0m
[30;1m556 | [0m[35m   This is a simple key/value dictionary, using the `name` property for each `Widget` as the keys.[0m
[30;1m557 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m558 | [0m[35mThe latter is a preferred as a symmetrical solution is provided to access all the data for each[0m

[30;1m75 | [0m[35m<http://martinfowler.com/eaaDev/SeparatedPresentation.html>`__.  No matter what term you use, the[0m
[30;1m76 | [0m[35mconcept is easy: use a separate class to handle your persistent data storage.[0m
[30;1m77 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m78 | [0m[35mIn more concrete terms, let's have a closer look at the contact_list sample.  This consists of 3[0m
[30;1m79 | [0m[35mbasic classes:[0m
[30;1m80 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m81 | [0m[35m1. `ContactModel`: This is the model.  It stores simple contact details in a sqlite in-memory[0m

[30;1m5 | [0m[35m------------[0m
[30;1m6 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m7 | [0m[35mAsciimatics provides a `widgets` sub-package that allows you to create interactive text user[0m
[30;1m8 | [0m[35minterfaces.  At its heart, the logic is quite simple, reusing concepts from standard web and[0m
[30;1m9 | [0m[35mdesktop GUI frameworks.[0m
[30;1m10 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m11 | [0m[35m1. The basic building block for your text UI is a `Widget`.  There is a set of standard ones[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m719[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m

[30;1m891 | [0m[35m   the user moves to a new Scene or when the screen is resized.[0m
[30;1m892 | [0m[35m2. :py:meth:`~.Widget.update` - This is where you should put the logic to draw your widget.  It[0m
[30;1m893 | [0m[35m   gets called every time asciimatics needs to redraw the screen (and so should always draw the[0m
[30;1m894 | [0m[35m   entire widget).[0m

[30;1m896 | [0m[35m   keyboard events.[0m

[30;1m866 | [0m[35m        """[0m
[30;1m867 | [0m[35m        Create a clone of this Effect into a new Screen.[0m
[30;1m868 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m869 | [0m[35m        :param screen: The new Screen object to clone into.[0m
[30;1m870 | [0m[35m        :param scene: The new Scene object to clone into.[0m
[30;1m871 | [0m[35m        """[0m
[30;1m872 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m723[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/asciimatics-1.15.0/doc/source/widgets.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m848 | [0m[35mthe same internal state as the old, etc. Asciimatics provides a standard interface (the `clone`[0m
[30;1m849 | [0m[35mmethod) to help you out here.[0m
[30;1m850 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m851 | [0m[35mWhen the running `Scene` is resized (and passed back into the Screen as the start scene), the new[0m
[30;1m852 | [0m[35m`Scene` will run through all the `Effects` in the old copy looking for any with a `clone` method.[0m
[30;1m853 | [0m[35mIf it finds one, it will call it with 2 parameters: the new `Screen` and the new `Scene` to own the[0m
[30;1m854 | [0m[35mcloned `Effect`.  This allows you to take full control of how the new `Effect` is recreated.[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m724[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m

[30;1m839 | [0m[35m            last_scene = e.scene[0m
[30;1m840 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m841 | [0m[35mThis will allow you to decide how all your UI should look whenever the screen is resized and will[0m
[30;1m842 | [0m[35m restart at the Scene that was playing at the time of the resizing.[0m
[30;1m843 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m844 | [0m[35mRestoring state[0m
[30;1m845 | [0m[35m~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m725[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m838 | [0m[35m        except ResizeScreenError as e:[0m
[30;1m839 | [0m[35m            last_scene = e.scene[0m

[30;1m768 | [0m[35mAdding other effects[0m
[30;1m769 | [0m[35m~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~[0m
[30;1m770 | [0m[35mSince Frames are just another Effect, they can be combined with any other Effect in a Scene.  For[0m
[30;1m771 | [0m[35mexample, this will put a simple input form over the top of the animated Julia set Effect:[0m
[30;1m772 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m773 | [0m[35m.. code-block:: python[0m
[30;1m774 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m736[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000610[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m

   Pattern: [32m\s(apt|apt\-get|aria2c|arp|ash|awk|base64|bash|bpftrace|busybox|cat|chmod|chown|cp|cpan|cpulimit|crontab|csh|curl|cut|dash|dd|diff|dmesg|dmsetup|dnf|docker|dpkg|easy_install|ed|emacs|env|expand|expect|facter|find|finger|flock|fmt|ftp|gawk|gdb|gimp|git|grep|head|iftop|ionice|ip|irb|jjs|journalctl|jrunscript|ksh|ld\.so|ldconfig|logsave|ltrace|lua|mail|mawk|mount|mtr|mv|mysql|nano|nawk|nc|nice|nl|nmap|node|od|openssl|perl|pg|php|pic|pico|pip|puppet|readelf|red|rlogin|rlwrap|rpm|rpmquery|rsync|ruby|run\-mailcap|run\-parts|rvim|scp|screen|script|sed|service|setarch|sftp|shuf|smbclient|socat|sort|sqlite3|ssh|start\-stop\-daemon|stdbuf|strace|systemctl|tail|tar|taskset|tclsh|tcpdump|tee|telnet|tftp|time|timeout|tmux|top|ul|unexpand|uniq|unshare|vi|vim|watch|wget|whois|wish|xargs|xxd|yum|zsh|zypper)\s[0m
[30;1m755 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m756 | [0m[35mAt a high level, you need to decide what you want to achieve.  The basic options are as follows.[0m
[30;1m757 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m758 | [0m[35m1. If you just want to have some extra Frames on the same Screen - e.g. pop-up windows - that's[0m
[30;1m759 | [0m[35m   fine.  Just use the existing classes (see below)![0m
[30;1m760 | [0m[35m2. If you want to be able to draw other content outside of your existing Frame(s), you probably[0m
[30;1m761 | [0m[35m   want to use other Effects.[0m

[30;1m672 | [0m[35mDealing with Ctrl+S[0m
[30;1m673 | [0m[35m~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~[0m
[30;1m674 | [0m[35mBack in the days when terminals really were separate machines connected over wires to a computer,[0m
[30;1m675 | [0m[35mit was necessary to be able to signal that the terminal needed time to catch up.  This was done[0m
[30;1m676 | [0m[35musing software flow control, using the Ctrl+S/Ctrl+Q control codes to tell the computer to[0m
[30;1m677 | [0m[35mstop/restart sending text.[0m
[30;1m678 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m621 | [0m[35m~~~~~~~~~~~~[0m
[30;1m622 | [0m[35mWhen constructing a Frame, you can specify whether it is modal or not using the `is_modal`[0m
[30;1m623 | [0m[35mparameter.  Modal Frames will not allow any input to filter through to other Effects in the Scene,[0m
[30;1m624 | [0m[35mso when one is on top of all other Effects, this means that only it will see the user input.[0m
[30;1m625 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m626 | [0m[35mThis is commonly used for, but not limited to, notifications to the user that must be acknowledged[0m
[30;1m627 | [0m[35m(as implemented by :py:obj:`.PopUpDialog`).[0m

[30;1m565 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m566 | [0m[35m1. You can query each Widget directly, using the `value` property.  This returns the current value[0m
[30;1m567 | [0m[35m   the user has entered at any time (even when the Frame is not active).  Note that it may be[0m

[30;1m570 | [0m[35m   every Widget in the former as a dictionary, using the Widget `name` properties for the keys.[0m

[30;1m433 | [0m[35mcurrent Screen.  The Frame will be recreated when the screen is resized and so you will use more or[0m
[30;1m434 | [0m[35mless real estate appropriately.[0m
[30;1m435 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m436 | [0m[35mFinally, you could also tell asciimatics to use an object to fill any remaining space.  This[0m

[30;1m16 | [0m[35m#. If writing a new Effect, consider why it can't be handled by a combination of a new[0m
[30;1m17 | [0m[35m   Renderer and the :py:obj:`.Print` Effect.  For example, dynamic Effects such as[0m
[30;1m18 | [0m[35m   :py:obj:`.Snow` depend on the current Screen state to render each new image.[0m
[30;1m19 | [0m[35m#. Go the extra yard.  This project started on a whim to share the joy of someone starting out[0m
[30;1m20 | [0m[35m   programming back in the 1980s.  How do you sustain that joy?  Not just by writing code that[0m
[30;1m21 | [0m[35m   works, but by writing code that other programmers will admire.[0m

[30;1m331 | [0m[35mInput responsiveness[0m
[30;1m332 | [0m[35m^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^[0m
[30;1m333 | [0m[35mFirst things first, you should make sure that you're running at least version 1.11.  Once you[0m
[30;1m334 | [0m[35mhave that installed, you can use the ``allow_int`` option in :py:meth:`.play` to permit mouse[0m
[30;1m335 | [0m[35mand keyboard input to interrupt the normal frame refresh rate.[0m
[30;1m336 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m771[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m316 | [0m[35mor whether you want to minimize CPU usage inside a ``Frame``.  It then uses these hints and the[0m
[30;1m317 | [0m[35mcurrent application state to decide whether to draw a new frame into the double-buffer.[0m
[30;1m318 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m319 | [0m[35mThe first thing to look at is things that are not actually changing.  For example if you use the[0m
[30;1m320 | [0m[35m``Print`` Effect to display a static piece of text (like a ``FigletText`` renderer), the output[0m
[30;1m321 | [0m[35mnever changes and so you only need to draw it once.  in such cases, you should tell the Effect[0m
[30;1m322 | [0m[35mthat it is pointless to refresh by specifying ``speed=0`` on construction.[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m772[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000600[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Windows[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m

[30;1m312 | [0m[35mThe key to this optimization is to understand what you're drawing when.  The biggest cost in[0m
[30;1m313 | [0m[35mthe mainline loop is the actual re-drawing of all the content to the double-buffers, so asciimatics[0m
[30;1m314 | [0m[35monly does this when it knows something has, or may have, changed.  You give hints to asciimatics as[0m
[30;1m315 | [0m[35myou construct your application - for example the rate at which a ``Print`` Effect needs to redraw,[0m
[30;1m316 | [0m[35mor whether you want to minimize CPU usage inside a ``Frame``.  It then uses these hints and the[0m
[30;1m317 | [0m[35mcurrent application state to decide whether to draw a new frame into the double-buffer.[0m
[30;1m318 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m301 | [0m[35munresponsive in some scenario.  Either way, the solution is to reduce the work being done[0m
[30;1m302 | [0m[35mbehind the scenes for your application.  At a high-level you have 3 options.[0m
[30;1m303 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m304 | [0m[35m1. Switch off any animations you don't need.[0m
[30;1m305 | [0m[35m2. Move to a more responsive input loop.[0m

[30;1m37 | [0m[35mcould also be a bug in your system installation.[0m
[30;1m38 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m39 | [0m[35mCurses-based systems date back to an era when people connected to a computer via dumb terminals.[0m
[30;1m40 | [0m[35mEach terminal needed different control character sequences to tell it what to do.  These[0m
[30;1m41 | [0m[35mdifferences are handled by curses, which picks the right definition based on your `TERM`[0m
[30;1m42 | [0m[35menvironment variable.  If you have the wrong terminal definition, you may find that curses[0m
[30;1m43 | [0m[35mbelieves some fundamental services are unavailable to your application.  In particular, if[0m

[30;1m193 | [0m[35mthe following inside your terminal *should* fix up the mismatch.[0m

[30;1m139 | [0m[35mMany people run asciimatics on low-power systems and so care about CPU.  However[0m
[30;1m140 | [0m[35mthere is a trade-off between CPU usage and responsiveness of any User Interface[0m
[30;1m141 | [0m[35mor the slickness of any animation.  Asciimatics tries to handle this for you by[0m
[30;1m142 | [0m[35mlooking at when each ``Effect`` next wants to be redrawn and only refreshing the[0m
[30;1m143 | [0m[35m``Screen`` when needed.[0m
[30;1m144 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m145 | [0m[35mFor most use-cases, this default should be enough for your needs.  However,[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m947[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000600[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Windows[0m
  Severity: [36mModerate[0m, Confidence: [36mLow[0m
  Filename: [33m/asciimatics-1.15.0/doc/source/animation.rst[0m
   Pattern: [32m\s(advpack\.dll|appvlp|at|atbroker|bash|bginfo|bitsadmin|cdb|certutil|cl_invocation\.ps1|cl_mutexverifiers\.ps1|cmd|cmdkey|cmstp|comsvcs\.dll|control|csc|cscript|csi|devtoolslauncher|dfsvc|diskshadow|dnscmd|dnx|dotnet|dxcap|esentutl|eventvwr|excel|expand|extexport|extrac32|findstr|forfiles|ftp|gfxdownloadwrapper|gpscript|hh|ie4uinit|ieadvpack\.dll|ieaframe\.dll|ic|infdefaultinstall|installutil|jsc|makecab|manage-bde\.wsf|mavinject|mftrace|microsoft\.workflow\.compiler|mmc|msbuild|msconfig|msdeploy|msdt|mshta|mshtml\.dll|msc|msxsl|netsh|odbcconf|pcalua|pcwrun|pcwutl\.dll|pester\.bat|powerpnt|presentationhost|pubprn\.vbs|rcsi|reg|regasm|regedit|register-cimprovider|regsvcs|regsvr32|rpcping|rundll32|runonce|runscripthelper|sc|schtasks|scriptrunner|setupapi\.dll|shdocvw\.dll|shell32\.dll|slmgr\.vbs|sqldumper|sqlps|sqltoolsps|squirrel|syncappvpublishingserver|syncappvpublishingserver\.vbs|syssetup\.dll|te|tracker|tttracer|update|url\.dll|verclsid|vsjitdebugger|wab|winrm\.vbs|winword|wmic|wscript|wsl|wsreset|xwizard|zipfldr\.dll)\s[0m
[30;1m73 | [0m[35m2. A :py:obj:`.DynamicPath` which depends on the program state and so can only[0m
[30;1m74 | [0m[35m   be calculated when needed - e.g. because it depends on what key the user is[0m
[30;1m75 | [0m[35m   pressing.  These provide an abstract method - ``process_event()`` - that[0m
[30;1m76 | [0m[35m   must be overridden to handle any keys and Update the current coordinates[0m
[30;1m77 | [0m[35m   of the Path, to be returned the next time the Sprite asks for an update.[0m
[30;1m78 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m79 | [0m[35mThe full declaration of a Sprite is therefore something like this.[0m

[30;1m66 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m67 | [0m[35mMuch like Renderers, the paths come in 2 flavours:[0m
[30;1m68 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m69 | [0m[35m1. A :py:obj:`.Path` is a pre-defined path that can be fully determined at the[0m
[30;1m70 | [0m[35m   start of the program.  This provides 4 methods - ``jump_to()``, ``wait()``,[0m
[30;1m71 | [0m[35m   ``move_straight_to()`` and ``move_round_to()`` - to define the path.  Just[0m
[30;1m72 | [0m[35m   decide on the path and script it by chaining these methods together.[0m

[30;1m17 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m18 | [0m[35mAn Effect is basically an object that encodes something to be displayed on the[0m
[30;1m19 | [0m[35mScreen.  It can be anything from :py:obj:`.Print` that just displays some[0m
[30;1m20 | [0m[35mrendered text at a specific location for a certain time to :py:obj:`.Snow` that[0m
[30;1m21 | [0m[35madds dynamically generated falling snow to the Scene.  These are the building[0m
[30;1m22 | [0m[35mblocks of your animation and will be rendered in the strict order that they[0m
[30;1m23 | [0m[35mappear in the Scene, so most of the time you want to put foreground Effects[0m

[30;1m158 | [0m[35m----------------------[0m
[30;1m159 | [0m[35mIf you cannot allow asciimatics to schedule each frame itself, e.g. because you[0m
[30;1m160 | [0m[35mare using an asynchronous framework like gevent, asyncio or twisted, that's[0m
[30;1m161 | [0m[35mfine.  Asciimatics is designed to run in tiny time slices that are ideal for [0m
[30;1m162 | [0m[35msuch a framework.  All you need to do is call :py:meth:`.set_scenes` to set up[0m
[30;1m163 | [0m[35myour scenes and :py:meth:`.draw_next_frame` (every 1/20 of a second) to draw[0m
[30;1m164 | [0m[35mthe next frame.[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m953[0m[34m of [0m[33m968[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m152 | [0m[35masciimatics is being too conservative and you need to refresh the ``Screen``[0m
[30;1m153 | [0m[35mbefore it thinks you need to do so.  In this case, you can simply force its hand[0m

[30;1m156 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m123 | [0m[35m   that has just one ``Particle`` that shoots vertically up the Screen to hit a[0m

[30;1m126 | [0m[35m   ``StarExplosion``.  This is a ``ParticleEmitter`` that spawns many[0m

[30;1m69 | [0m[35m1. A :py:obj:`.Path` is a pre-defined path that can be fully determined at the[0m
[30;1m70 | [0m[35m   start of the program.  This provides 4 methods - ``jump_to()``, ``wait()``,[0m
[30;1m71 | [0m[35m   ``move_straight_to()`` and ``move_round_to()`` - to define the path.  Just[0m
[30;1m72 | [0m[35m   decide on the path and script it by chaining these methods together.[0m
[30;1m73 | [0m[35m2. A :py:obj:`.DynamicPath` which depends on the program state and so can only[0m
[30;1m74 | [0m[35m   be calculated when needed - e.g. because it depends on what key the user is[0m
[30;1m75 | [0m[35m   pressing.  These provide an abstract method - ``process_event()`` - that[0m

[30;1m56 | [0m[35m-----------------[0m
[30;1m57 | [0m[35mA :py:obj:`.Sprite` is a special Effect designed to move some rendered text[0m
[30;1m58 | [0m[35maround the Screen, thus creating an animated character.  As such, they work[0m
[30;1m59 | [0m[35mlike any other Effect, needing to be placed in a Scene and passed to the Screen[0m
[30;1m60 | [0m[35m(through the ``play()`` method) to be displayed.  They typically take:[0m
[30;1m61 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m62 | [0m[35m- a set of Renderers to animate the motion of the character when moving in any[0m
[30;1m63 | [0m[35m  direction[0m

[30;1m36 | [0m[35mTiming Effects[0m
[30;1m37 | [0m[35m--------------[0m
[30;1m38 | [0m[35mWhen playing animations, asciimatics will try to redraw the Screen 20 times a[0m
[30;1m39 | [0m[35msecond.  Each iteration of the loop produces a new frame (no relation to the[0m
[30;1m40 | [0m[35mwidget class `Frame`) and increments the frame counter.[0m
[30;1m41 | [0m[35m[0m
